content: "All it took was the gunshot fired outside his Walker County home to trigger training ingrained in former Navy SEAL Marcus Luttrell, the lone survivor of a dramatic battle in Afghanistan in 2005. He did a sweep through the house. Checked on his mother. And bolted out the door, where he found dead his beloved Labrador retriever, Dasy, a dog given to him to help him recover from his own wounds and the loss of his fellow Navy comrades." "http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/front/6365427.html" What kind of sick person just goes around shooting dogs? If you read the whole article you'll see these criminals are lucky they were just arrested.
reply: "All it took was the gunshot fired outside his Walker County home to trigger training ingrained in former Navy SEAL Marcus Luttrell, the lone survivor of a dramatic battle in Afghanistan in 2005. If you read the whole article you'll see these criminals are lucky they were just arrested.
title: Navy Cross recipient Marcus Luttrell's dog killed-- sad story

title: Navy Cross recipient Marcus Luttrell's dog killed-- sad story

content: "On April 5, 2009, four teenage males approached Luttrell's property and fatally wounded his dog, Dasy, with a .357 Magnum revolver at approximately 1 A.M. Each letter of the name "Dasy" represents one of the fallen members of his team. She was given to him in recovery to help him through rehabilitation. Luttrell proceeded to track the individuals through four counties in his truck until Texas Rangers apprehended the individuals. Upon arrest, the suspects verbally threatened Luttrell's life and taunted him. Alfonso Hernandez was arrested on-scene and charged with animal cruelty whilst Michael Edmonds has not yet been charged. On April 7, he turned himself in, was booked, and posted his bail. The other two individuals were not charged. The males are believed to also be behind the killings of other neighborhood canines." "The price of freedom is eternal vigilance." Thomas Jefferson

content: quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: The article says Luttrell had snuck up on the perps and had one of them "dead to rights" with his pistol - they are very lucky he had the restraint not to kill them then and there, because I don't think there is a jury in TX that would have convicted him. An established defense for killing someone who's killed your dog is to claim temporary insanity. It's worked in a number of cases. And at least in my case it wouldn't even be a lie. A guy once kicked a dog I owned, and when I regained control of myself, the guy was a bloody pulp, and I really have no memory of doing this. If some freinds hadn't of come along and pulled me off of him, I have no idea what would have occured - But absolutely, I could have honestly claimed temporary insanity. Dave

content: quote: and when I regained control of myself, the guy was a bloody pulp, and I really have no memory of doing this. If some freinds hadn't of come along and pulled me off of him, I have no idea what would have occured - But absolutely, I could have honestly claimed temporary insanity. I posted on something like this a couple weeks ago Dave, about the gal that was beaten and no one helped her,that thread. I understand exactly what you're saying Dave, had it happen to me, had a bystander not shoved me and made me come to my sences, I most certianly would have killed the man. A blackout, I hear is what they call it, similar to a alcholic blackout, no memory of it, in my case, I can remember bits and pieces, thats it and I was stoned cold sober at the time, I understand. This guy has been thru enough, how someone could shoot his dog is just plain crazy. He has every right in my opinion to beat the man to inches from death.
